newsitem.title: USA: CBOT corn closes lower on Sparks estimate, soy.
newsitem.headline: CBOT corn closes lower on Sparks estimate, soy.

text.p: A bearish crop estimate from the CEO of Memphis-based analytical firm Sparks Companies and a sharp drop in soybeans pressed CBOT corn futures to a lower close, traders said.
"With guys like Brunthave coming out with a crop like that the burden of proof is on the bull," said Steve Bruce of E.D. and F. Man International.

Sparks Companies CEO Carrol Brunthaver Monday told a National Grain and Feed Association conference in Kansas City the 1996 U.S. corn crop would total 9.3 to 9.4 billion bushels, above USDA's November forecast for 9.265 billion.
But the nearby December contract gained on spreads with other months on slow farmer selling and no deliveries on that month plus better-than-expected exports.
"Exports were bad for everything but corn," a trader said.
USDA's weekly export inspections report showed U.S. corn inspections for the week ended December 5 at 49.598 million bushels, above trade expectations for 45.0 to 48.0 million bushels.
Corn closed 1/2 to 3-1/2 cents per bushel lower, with December down 1/2 at $2.66-3/4. March was down 1-1/2 at $2.64-1/2.
